1. A 62-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive difficulty walking due to unsteady gait and frequent falls. He reports shooting, lightning-like pains in his legs and occasional numbness that began insidiously. On examination, there is decreased proprioception and vibration sense in his lower limbs, along with areflexia of the knees and ankles. He also describes urinary urgency and occasional incontinence that developed recently. The patient has a remote history of untreated syphilis diagnosed over 20 years ago but never completed therapy. Romberg’s test is positive, and his pupils are irregular and unreactive to light but constrict with accommodation (Argyll Robertson pupils). MRI of the spine shows no compressive lesions, but cerebrospinal fluid VDRL is positive. These findings are consistent with tabes dorsalis, a late manifestation of neurosyphilis affecting the dorsal columns and dorsal roots.

output:
THINKING: I need to be honest about my troubles, but I also don’t really understand everything about what's wrong. I’m feeling pretty scared about these things I’ve been experiencing — the pain, my walking, all of it. Maybe I should just tell the doctor simple and clear what’s been bothering me the most lately.

ANSWER: Well, I’m 62 and I’m a man. It’s just that I’ve been having a hard time walking these past few months, and I keep falling even though I try not to. Sometimes I get shooting pains in my legs, and I feel numb sometimes, like I can’t really feel anything. It’s all kind of scary and I don’t really know what’s going on.
